13 Going On 31

13æ­³ã‹ã‚‰31æ­³ã¾ã§

30 min read

â€œYou teach me now how cruelÂ youâ€™veÂ beenâ€”cruel and false. Why did you despise me? Why did you betray your own heart, Cathy? I have not one word of comfort. You deserve this. You have killed yourself. Yes, you may kiss me, and cry; and wring out my kisses and tears:Â theyâ€™llÂ blight youâ€”theyâ€™llÂ damn you. You loved meâ€”then what right had you to leave me? What rightâ€”answer meâ€”for the poor fancy you felt for Linton? Because misery and degradation, and death, and nothing that God or Satan could inflict would have parted us, you, of your own will, did it. I have not broken your heartâ€”you have broken it; and in breaking it, you have broken mine. So much the worse for me, that I am strong. Do I want to live? What kind of living will it be when youâ€”oh, God! would you like to live with your soul in the grave?â€

Emily BrontÃ«, â€œWuthering Heightsâ€

I canâ€™t believe Iâ€™m writing this! Let alone writing, period. Itâ€™s been a full year since my last post, where I celebrated turning thirty in my favorite place in the world. Today, I am back in Hokkaido.
My website perished over the past year due to budget constraints, but now a new and improved version is slowly coming together.
Just like me. I was so alive between 27-30 years old. Now, my life feels dead again.
How did I get here? Why does my 31 self mirror me at 13? And what have I learned?
Last year, I drew thirty conclusions. Now, I am not so sure. I already know my strengths and weaknesses. I know my potential and worth. I know what I can offer, and what needs work.
Having neglected writing in the past year, I feel compelled to trace it first, and then see how Iâ€™ve matured.

My Life at 30

February 2025

  • Trying to prevent my first suffocating relationship. This new guy showers me with care, and breaks the cycle of ghosting in my (unrequited) love life. But demands constant attention, monitors me to ensure that â€œno one stealsâ€ me, and blames me for turning him mad
  • He suggests celebrating my birthday as friends, shows up with a cake and presents, pressures me to act like a couple, and says he wants to settle down. On VALENTINEâ€™S DAY
  • My best birthday, and one of my happiest days, one year ago in snowy Hokkaido, at my favorite ryokan, with my favorite hot spring and tour guide; seeing penguins and savoring my favorite sushi chain
  • Meeting another grandma from Hokkaido who takes me under her wing (February 2026 update: she sends me presents every few months, I feel so unworthy)
  • A Japanese aunt who exploited and stalked me in 2023 texting: â€œHappy birthday! Where are you?â€
  • Teaching myself music production, creating songs almost daily, and resenting my friends for ignoring my passions
  • Returning to Japanese language school and realizing that my recent conclusion - â€œpeople wonâ€™t make time for me even if they want to because Iâ€™m not special enoughâ€ - is false. The classmate Iâ€™d been trying to befriend isnâ€™t too busy for others
  • Studying business Japanese and trying to socialize with other classmates, who pick phones over friendship. A creepy Israeli student from another class comes to mine every day during recess and breaking up my conversations with my classmates
  • Giving the love bomber another chance and resisting his gaslighting until we break up
  • Wondering why guys I dated in Taiwan still text me and whether I should have moved to Taipei
  • Winning a prize at the schoolâ€™s kanji contest
  • Deciding that I finally want monogamy

March 2025

  • Dating a famous guy who treats me to fancy places, showers me with presents, and offers to fly me to his residences. Not my first time, but still baffling, since I am used to ghosting, and feel unworthy
  • Winning an award at a Japanese speech contest in front of a few hundred people and industry officials, but failing to ç©ºæ°—ã‚’èª­ã‚€
  • Fainting at a clinic after the nurse canâ€™t draw my blood
  • My chest tightening every day because the person Iâ€™m in love with doesnâ€™t know I exist
  • Struggling to find this spark by dating locals
  • Making it up to the love bomber on his birthday, exchanging sincere apologies, and achieving my first romantic closure
  • Realizing that my relationships are asymmetrical
  • Understanding that friendship and romance work differently in East Asia. The former is distant, while the latter is stifling. Many Asians seem to learn deep connection through Westerners, and then love bomb so as to not lose their chance to be open about their true self
  • Turning into Charlotte from Sex and the City. â€œNever sleep with someone you like on the first date.â€ I start taking it slow, and eschew meaningless hookups. Iâ€™m still a Samantha - until romance is involved. (In retrospect, no one I date ghosts me from now on)
  • Spending a magical week with a tourist whose country I am banned from. The only time in my life where I feel like a teenager experiencing his first romance. There is mutual love (finally!) and, even though I donâ€™t believe in fate, signs. Itâ€™s the beginning of spring, and heâ€™s never seen snow; the forecast predicts warm sun, when thick snow blankets Tokyo
  • Bidding him farewell on the way to my first shift at a place that traumatized my adolescence - a synagogue. Wiping my cheeks and putting on a face at work
  • Food poisoning from the synagogue making me so sick for a week, that I almost need an ambulance. While devastated that the tourist is gone
  • Finding myself in yet another long-distance situationship

April 2025

  • Relishing my first cherry blossoms in Tokyo, but feeling lonely since my loved ones live abroad
  • A Taiwanese uncle twice my age arriving in Tokyo with a present for me: a duck figurine, slang for male prostitute. He showed me around Taiwan two years ago, and now comes to Tokyo to meet a â€œwoman pen palâ€ he has feelings for
  • Plucking up the courage to do something that requires a lot of confidence, only to experience my worst night of clubbing, and one of my most degrading experiences. I feel ugly, and cry myself to sleep
  • Starting the last term in my beloved school on the next day, appreciating life as a student, and growing tired of the anti-social vibe in class
  • Starting to chase things that scare me. If I donâ€™t put myself out there, I will stagnate and merely exist
  • Meeting a tourist from Europe who feels like the read deal from the first moment. Wise and goofy, mature and young, Eastern and Western, passionate and Zen
  • Cursing distance for curtailing my best romantic and platonic connections
  • Finding that my EU passport application is successful in proving my eligibility, yet a new language law will ruin it

May 2025

  • A rocky Golden Week, in which I perform an original song live for the first time; finally enjoy clubbing as much as my first time two years ago, when a toxic ex resurfaces to ask for tips on hooking up with Israelis (exactly one month before my pathetic plan to make it up for him on his birthday); arguing over his manipulations for hours until dawn, until he calls me a â€œfictional characterâ€ who makes everything up; losing the part of me that believes in romance; and, a day later, meeting a new guy (who, in hindsight, becomes my most stable, respectful, and consistent relationship)
  • Realizing my parents and exes tend to gaslight, and re-having my ongoing nightmares from middle school
  • Understanding the meaning of â€œbad romanceâ€. I crave someone who hurts me and claims weâ€™re just friends. Iâ€™m â€œon my own, kidâ€, but â€œI can do it with a broken heartâ€, and â€œI can fix himâ€. (Then, discovering that people donâ€™t want to be fixed)
  • Realizing that my life can be summed up in two words: feeling invisible. The first guy I dated seriously was the first to see me. He promised to be there for me, then hit block
  • Breaking into tears over all thisâ€¦ while having sex
  • My psoriasis coming back instead of people
  • Finding a cure in songwriting (and steroids), shooting a music video
  • Attending Tokyoâ€™s most famous festivals, which pale in comparison to the countryside
  • Falling out of love with people who show me their true face
  • A Taiwanese guy I dated a year ago randomly texting me â€œI love you, I will come visit youâ€
  • The Japanese grandma complaining when I donâ€™t reply to her constant messages. â€œWeâ€™re like family,â€ she says, â€œand meeting you was a once-in-a-lifetime encounterâ€
  • Job hunting to prevent my return to Israel, where I have to hide my true self and live a lie (this already happened in 2020 after school in England)
  • Having my first panic attack in three years. My visa is about to expire, my money is about to run out, and I dedicate every day to making songs that all of my friends ignore. Everything I do is a failure
  • Betraying my values and agreeing to full-time work at the synagogue
  • Meditating at night for two weeks, embracing pain, and stabilizing my mental state

June 2025

  • Dating Tokyo locals. Itâ€™s slow and steady, but the chemistry is low
  • Wondering if requited love can be as grand as unrequited
  • Heating up with the Golden Week guy, who calls me every day now, opens up about his secrets, and communicates candidly to ensure I donâ€™t get hurt
  • Dreading another ghosting, and realizing that liars have turned me suspicious
  • One week with five exams at school, the governmentâ€™s notorious Business Japanese Test, a part time job, performing live again, a Japanese work visa application, a European passport application, and volunteering at a disappointingly tame Tokyo Pride, where I see the blocking ex and club with shy locals
  • Negotiating a contract rife with absurd clauses copy-pasted by a clueless immigration lawyer, since my boss neither read it nor wrote a word
  • Discovering that Japanese people can be distant and artificially polite to everyone, not just Westerners, out of fear of being a burden. Lamenting this cultural pressure to be quiet, and wishing to support them
  • Graduating! RIP my student era
  • NOT getting paid because my boss neglects my salary, then asks me to break the visa law
  • â€œMy heart aches for you,â€ says the GW guy, â€œI want to take care of you.â€ Turns out he also fears me ghosting him

  • Mourning my impossible romances and friends who are gone

July 2025

  • One week where I take the JLPT N2, apply for a work visa while my boss ignores my request for documents required by the immigration office, and pack for a last-minute silent retreat

  • Meditating from dawn to night while sitting still for almost two weeks at a Buddhist centre in the countryside, where talking, making eye contact, using technology, exercising, reading, and writing is forbidden. I do the latter on my first day, agonize over my disobedience, confess, almost get expelled, and abide by the rules; suffer constant pain and cramps, disagree with the brainwashing lectures, and starve from two meals per day; enjoy the digital detox and clean air, rewrite an old story, compose five songs, and draft three albums; recall why art is my ride or die, followed by health and the people I love; count the hours to freedom, but then appreciate this experience so much, that I almost extend my stay
  • Second time where I go on a digital detox in Japan and check out with a local guy I feel tension with. Last time I was too shy to ask for his number, but this time I wait at the train station, and we hang out
  • Returning to life in the worldâ€™s busiest hub feeling cleansed and peaceful; missing neither drama, nor humans; eager to write - only to drop my electronics into the bath
  • Not knowing who I am anymore: an introverted writer who doesnâ€™t need people, or an extroverted adventurer who aches for love
  • Reuniting with a guy I dated two years ago in Korea. Neither of us thought weâ€™d meet again
  • Sweating every day while dying of boredom, because I can afford neither a computer nor a trip on my last days of freedom before work

  • â€œYou changed me and gave me hope,â€ says GW. I can help people, after all? We admit our feelings, but agree to just be friends

August 2025

  • The beginning of my worst period since 2022.   • FINALLY GETTING PAID AND BUYING A COMPUTER

October 2025

  • Fighting with my mom every day on the trip because she wrinkles her nose incessantly and screams at me for creating a bad itinerary, which she never deigned to glance at in the six months it took me to plan it
  • Getting along with my sister, enjoying Japan and our precious time together
  • Agonizing because I love my mom but feel mistreated by her for a decade

  • Another rocky Valentineâ€™s Day, in which the Taiwanese uncle confesses his love for me; I realize I enable clingy people by acting nice, and block him, the lover bomber, and Israeli student; perform stand-up comedy and new songs at a queer party with improved confidence and success; sleep two hours; then fly to Hokkaido
  • Deciding to find a balance between my mental serenity after the silent retreat, and my tendency to follow the heat of the moment. Maybe itâ€™s good none of my long-distance romances worked. Itâ€™s definitely bad when people pressure me with presents and extreme attention

My Life at 13

As a child, I dabbled in a lot of arts.
I mailed the most famous childrenâ€™s author in Israel books with fan-fiction that I wrote.
I created a theatre show that I performed every year from kindergarten to middle school.
I played the piano for six years.
I was in the school choir, and opened the graduation show with a solo.
I painted every week and created costumes.
Until middle school, when I was bullied and alone. I quit my hobbies, studied Japanese, and hid my thoughts and emotions. On my 14th birthday, I journaled about my growth.
(The following is a translation of my diary in Hebrew - I will upload pictures of it soon)

16 February 2009

Iâ€™m not excited at all, I just feel like itâ€™s another normal day. Always, every year, I remember waking up with a smile on my face [â€¦] a million kids bullied me and called me gay, made impressions of me and cussed at me. Iâ€™m used to these things but the weird thing is that today it happened more than ever!

Here I mention a new Pokemon game Iâ€™d wanted for three years. In January 2026, I finally got Pokemon Scarlet, which Iâ€™d wanted for three years.

Iâ€™ll probably go out with B and A to a charity event, which sounds fun but kind of screws up my plan to come out in front of them. I think the timing is good and the opportunity as well and weâ€™ll probably be alone (mom at home? Need to check) and the most important thing is that I feel ready, and Iâ€™ve been planning this for two weeks now. I have messed-up genes and I hate my body and my appearance, and I am under so much stress that I donâ€™t know what to do. I used to cry a lot and this year I cried only once. I think itâ€™s because somehow, with time, everything healed. The bullying only became worse but I just became strongerâ€¦ and a lot more. It doesnâ€™t get to me at all anymore, those words donâ€™t bug me at all at all, and all the wounds, the grudge and the anger that have accumulated inside me all these years are gone. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s good â€“ I mean, itâ€™s good that Iâ€™ve grown up, that it doesnâ€™t get to me anymore all those things and that Iâ€™m better than that. Itâ€™s very hard for me to open up, and Iâ€™m really scared of how people might react. There are so many who hate my kind of people, and especially you can see it in school. And the thing is Iâ€™m d=y=i=n=g for a hug, for touch, for warmth and love, and a boyfriend. I feel really desperate, Iâ€™m ready for a boyfriend but I understand itâ€™s really really not simple. It will happen with timeâ€¦ Iâ€™m sure. :P

And now itâ€™s all coming back to me. Just as Iâ€™m writing all this. Iâ€™m also beginning to formulate a certain theory about my behaviour. I also think after what happened this year: my heart-to-heart conversations with H, and her decision to cut ties with me, really hurt me even though I know it was entirely my fault. I know I hurt her, a lot, and she even told me it was irreparable damage. And she asked me to cut ties. And it made me sad as hell because I really love her [platonically] and itâ€™s important for me to stay on good terms with her. I understood her and therefore did as she asked. But I was sad.

It also hurt my relationship with B. And suddenly we began to talk, and she also told me the situation didnâ€™t make her happy. And now Iâ€™m happy like I donâ€™t know whatâ€¦ the relationship has gotten so great. Weâ€™re closer than ever. Iâ€™m in the best relationship with the girls, all of them [â€¦]

Anyway, things are completely fixed. Today was too cramped and I didnâ€™t get enough privacy â€“ only now I finally have some time to breathe, and barely too. I havenâ€™t eaten dinner yet (21:00), and I also need to finish the manga that Ziv from Japanese lent me and return it to him tomorrow because Iâ€™ve had it for a month already. And Iâ€™m really tired, Iâ€™m falling asleep as Iâ€™m writing this. But itâ€™s important for me to write all this. I guess the real recreation on my birthday is mental and emotional discharge to my diary, writing and organizing my thoughts and emotions, which I think is a very important thing, especially in my predicament and need.

Besides Iâ€™m not excited at all on this day, and I thought about it and I think itâ€™s not for nothing: everything is connected to everything, and even in this matter. When I shut myself down emotionally over the last few months I grew up A LOT. A LOT. So, while all these last years I was just radiant, over the moon â€“ I couldnâ€™t take the smile off my face on my birthdays â€“ this year Iâ€™m not. And it also shows my maturation. Not the physical one, which unfortunately came many years too soon, but emotional maturation. And Iâ€™m happy for that and thrilled, and very proud of myself, and I think it was the best present I couldâ€™ve asked for my birthday. I finish this diary, which I love so so much, with my favourite characters and series â€“ Happy Potter, which will forever be a part of my life â€“ with official maturation, wisdom, deep knowledge, and most importantly a lot of order within me. All this writing made me organise my thoughts and understand things better, and Iâ€™m sorry I didnâ€™t write all this time in the diary because Iâ€™m SURE! it wouldâ€™ve helped me a long time ago, and I couldâ€™ve saved myself great sorrow, but the important thing is that itâ€™s here! I plan in the very near future to tell B, I donâ€™t know who else right now, about me being gay, and even more about myself that is no less important. I will start with a journey to find my self, and of course a new diary! So, to be continued. ğŸ˜Š

My Life at 31

Everything about my existence is summed up in the above diary entry. Iâ€™ve always felt like an outsider, a stranger to my species; an alien in a world of monsters.
Itâ€™s taken me years to emerge from my spacesuit. At 30, I was finally on stage again. Iâ€™d focused on writing for fifteen years, but by 31, found myself exploring multiple mediums: prose, poetry, music, and comedy.
Since last winter, I wrote fifty songs, and progressed from basic, off-key piano notes to multilayered productions. I donâ€™t know what Iâ€™m doing, and none of it sounds professional - but isnâ€™t that part of the road?

16 February 2026

Like I wrote one year ago, there are so many things I wish to pursue, but cannot. I am confident in my abilities and vision, yet even the people closest to me dismiss my writing as poor.
Humans can thrive together. The idea that there is a limited number of success in the world is capitalist to a fault.
Arrogance is loving yourself more than others.
Insecurity is loving yourself less than others.
Confidence is loving yourself and others.
Delusion is loving yourself despite not knowing who you are. You deny your weaknesses, and repress your actions. It is so freeing to encounter someone authentically their own: so you shower them with love, to prevent abandonment; and hatred, when they donâ€™t feed your ego.
This is okay.
Things happen. Everything is forgivable, as long as you admit fault and change course.
Which is why there is nothing more detrimental than someone who never apologizes.
None of us identify as a monster. Most of our offenses are unconscious. As a child, I pestered my classmates in a desperate attempt to have friends, only to end up in middle school alone. This pushed me to become considerate and thoughtful.
Now, I am better. I take criticism, make sacrifices, and weather storms. But I am still sensitive to people who are callous.
I shudder to think that I also hurt others.
Perhaps I make mistakes as much as the next person. But at least I try to correct them. When you call out abuse and the perpetrator denies, projects, and distorts - well, they donâ€™t care about inflicting pain anymore.
And I will never, ever, EVER! understand that. Family, friends, employers, exes: how can I make them see others - and themselves?
Humans can be humane. They simply donâ€™t want to. I canâ€™t change someone who doesnâ€™t want to change; the only solution is to let go.
Iâ€™m not adept at this. But I think that one mustnâ€™t excel at letting go. If you really care about something, it will always be in your thoughts.
Itâ€™s such a bitter blow, learning that someone already let go.
I still dream about people I love. I still have nightmares about people I loathe.
As for those I love AND loatheâ€¦
Once they show you their true colors, youâ€™re stuck with what they do, while recalling what they can do.
I would stay off social media, which exacerbates this tension, but artists must build a platform in todayâ€™s digital world.
Messaging can be so distant, compared to hearing someoneâ€™s voice.
Alienation permeates the world. But enough complaining about it nonstop. I want to be fun and funny; I will never be as young as I am in any given moment.
And Iâ€™m grateful for the callous people. They taught me what mistakes to avoid. Now, itâ€™s up to me to discover what else is out there, through mistakes of my own.
I am young at heart, and my body feels strong. Iâ€™m so lucky to be alive and intact. Age is just a number, so take nudes and leaps of faith. Text your crush!
At various points in my life, Iâ€™ve lost lovers and friends, all my money, health, sanity, support, success, possessions, reputation, confidence, appearance, dreams, and joy. So I donâ€™t have anything to lose anymore.
Apart from hope.
Nine years ago, I wrote thesis after thesis in university about how art can save us. Even when I create to a void, I feel it healing my soul.
And I know, just KNOW, that I have what it takes to spread the cure. Thereâ€™s nothing I want to do more than to show people that hope isnâ€™t dangerous. Life can be wonderful! A wild ride, full of highs and lows. We can be ourselves and find happiness, if we just SEE each other.
Itâ€™s so inspiring, living in a cruel world.
